page.title: 13Totternhoe Knolls
page.content: The Knolls over look the village of Totternhoe. It was once the site of an Iron Age fort and was one of several in the area. The highest part of the Knolls is called Castle Mound. Nearby is a depression in the ground called the Money Pit. The Knolls are now a haven for local flora and fauna and is supervised by the Beds and Hunts Naturalists Trust. The area is ideal for picnicing in during the warmer weather. There is a car park nearby and a signpost to it down on the road which runs through the village. There are troughs for the animals to drink from and stiles to mark out the rights of way. Also in this area is the cub hut and the lime kilns. The local quarry provided the stone for many local churches including Totternhoe and Dunstable.
